chunks.content: TastyTrade launched comprehensive backtesting feature in November 2024 covering 137 symbols with options data going back 13 years. Tool available on web platform for all US tastytrade customers and UK IG customers. CAPABILITIES: Test strategies across 10-year historical periods including major market events (2018 volatility spike, 2020 pandemic selloff, 2022 bear market). Input long/short options strategies, spreads with customizable expiration dates, strikes, and market conditions. Analytics include: total P/L, average P/L, overall ROC, win rates, average returns, maximum drawdowns. Michael Rechenthin (Head of R&D): 'Backtesting is a game-changer for traders looking to go from concept to confidence in their strategies.' USAGE: First week saw 200,000+ backtests run by customers. Expanding from 43 to 200 symbols. Gain years of insight in seconds by testing multiple scenarios and timeframes.

TastyTrade strategy recommendations based on extensive backtesting and qualitative data: (1) SELL OPTIONS WHEN IV IS HIGH - premiums elevated, mean reversion expected. (2) USE EXPIRATION CLOSEST TO 45 DTE - optimal balance of theta decay and time to manage. (3) SELL OPTIONS WITH 30 DELTA - ~70% probability of expiring worthless, good risk/reward. (4) TAKE PROFIT AT 50% OF PREMIUM - maximizes win rate, reduces tail risk. (5) SCALING STUDY - compared scaling with higher delta vs more contracts. Result: scaling with more contracts exposed position to significantly larger losses ($3,500 vs $1,800 worst case). Recommendation: scale with delta adjustments rather than quantity. CRITICAL INSIGHT: All recommendations based on actual backtest data across thousands of trades and multiple market cycles, not theory.

chunks.topic: Gamma Behavior Near Expiration - Critical Risks
chunks.content: GAMMA EXPLOSION: Gamma is highest for ATM options close to expiration. Front-month ATM option has MORE gamma than LEAPS at same strike because delta rapidly approaches 0 or 1.00. As expiration nears, ATM gamma spikes making 0DTE options EXTREMELY sensitive to small price changes. RISK CONUNDRUM: Closer to expiration = higher positive theta BUT also higher negative gamma. Stock price near strike = very high gamma AND theta simultaneously. Risk on short option can go from mild to hair-raising quickly if stock moves around strike. CONVEXITY WARNING: Double-edged sword - underestimating gamma risk near expiration causes significant P&L swings. Sizing positions properly is VITAL. 0DTE APPEAL VS DANGER: Fast profit potential drives 0DTE popularity, but heightened risk - much 'less time to be right'. AT EXPIRATION: ITM options behave like stock (delta near ±1), OTM options lose all sensitivity. With no further delta changes possible, gamma drops to ZERO.

chunks.topic: Three Ways to Manage Gamma Risk
chunks.content: GAMMA MANAGEMENT METHODS: (1) CLOSE - During expiration week when gamma growing and delta becoming unstable, close position entirely. Most conservative approach. (2) ROLL - Roll position to later expiration to reduce gamma exposure. Move from weekly to monthly, or monthly to 45+ DTE. Extends time and reduces gamma spike. (3) HEDGE - Actively adjust positions to maintain delta neutrality. Requires constant monitoring and execution. MARKET MAKER DYNAMICS: As expiration nears, market makers must hedge more aggressively due to gamma spikes. Can cause price pinning or increased volatility. Once gamma declines post-expiration, pressures subside. POSITIVE GAMMA ENVIRONMENT: Dealers long calls, hedging flows stabilize price movements, leads to LOWER volatility. NEGATIVE GAMMA ENVIRONMENT: Dealers short puts, hedging flows exacerbate price swings, leads to VOLATILITY EXPANSION. CRITICAL DECISION POINT: Expiration week is when gamma risk peaks - must have management plan in place BEFORE entering trade.

chunks.topic: Cash-Secured Put Entry Rules and Criteria
chunks.content: CASH REQUIREMENT: Must have 100% cash to purchase stock at strike price (100 shares × strike). Premium received may apply to margin requirement but full cash must be secured - hence 'cash-secured'. Buying power reduced by full obligation amount until position closed. MARKET OUTLOOK: Requires neutral-to-BULLISH forecast. Only use when comfortable OWNING underlying shares at that price - assignment always possible. Net cost (strike - premium) should be satisfactory entry point. STOCK SELECTION CRITERIA: (1) Companies you want to own long-term. (2) Solid fundamentals - strong balance sheets, stable earnings, good market position. (3) Current price acceptable for long-term holding. (4) High liquidity with tight bid-ask spreads. WARNING: Never write more puts than equivalent shares you're willing/able to purchase. Strategy becomes speculative if overextended. Assignment should not be financial burden.

chunks.topic: Cash-Secured Put Strike Selection and Management
chunks.content: STRIKE SELECTION: Sell ATM or OTM put (strike below current stock price). Consider first strike BELOW current price to increase assignment probability if goal is stock ownership. Rule: Choose strike you're happy to pay for stock long-term. POSITION SIZING RULE: If normally buy 100 shares per trade, sell 1 put contract. If buy 200 shares, sell 2 contracts. Scale proportionally to normal stock position size. PROFIT/LOSS PROFILE: Max profit = premium received (limited upside). Max loss = strike price if stock goes to zero (substantial but capped). Breakeven = strike - premium received. TIME DECAY: Your friend - want option price to approach zero. VOLATILITY: Want IV to DECREASE after entry - makes closing position cheaper. MANAGEMENT: Can close anytime, roll to later expiration, or accept assignment and own shares. NEVER sell puts on stocks you don't want to own.

chunks.topic: Poor Man's Covered Call (PMCC) Structure and Definition
chunks.content: PMCC DEFINITION: Long call diagonal spread - buy long-term ITM call instead of owning stock, sell short-term OTM call against it for income. Reduces capital requirement vs traditional covered call. STRUCTURE: LONG LEG (LEAPS) - Buy deep ITM call with delta >0.75 and DTE ≥90 days. Acts as stock replacement. Minimal time value. SHORT LEG - Sell OTM call with delta <0.35 and DTE <60 days. Generates income. Must expire BEFORE long call. CAPITAL EFFICIENCY: PMCC requires fraction of capital vs buying 100 shares. Example: $10,000 stock position vs $2,000-3,000 LEAPS position for similar exposure. RISK: Max loss = net debit paid to enter trade (cost of LEAPS minus premium collected). Occurs if both options expire worthless. Loss capped unlike naked call (unlimited risk). NEVER sell short call without owning stock or long call - creates naked call position.

chunks.topic: PMCC Critical Setup Rules and Strike Selection
chunks.content: STRUCTURING FORMULA (MANDATORY): [(Short call strike - LEAPS strike) + short call premium] MUST BE > Cost of LEAPS option. If this formula not satisfied, position has minuscule or NEGATIVE max profit potential. COST-TO-WIDTH GUIDELINE: Entry cost must be notably less than width of strikes. TastyTrade rule: trade cost <75% of strike width. Example: $5 wide strikes = max cost $3.75. LONG CALL (LEAPS) SELECTION: (1) Delta ABOVE 0.75 (acts like stock). (2) DTE at least 90 days, preferably 6-12 months. (3) MINIMAL time value component - if time value too high, go deeper ITM. (4) Strike selection must satisfy structuring formula. SHORT CALL SELECTION: (1) Delta BELOW 0.35 (~30 delta common). (2) DTE fewer than 60 days (30-45 typical). (3) OTM strike above current price. (4) Expires BEFORE long call. ENTRY EXECUTION: Always 'leg in' - buy long call FIRST, then sell short call. Use LIMIT ORDERS - LEAPS have wide bid-ask spreads. Avoid volatile market times.

PROFIT TAKING: Close short call at 50% max profit to lock gains and reduce risk. Can sell new short call immediately to continue generating income. ROLLING SHORT CALLS: When short call approaching expiration or hit profit target, roll out to next expiration cycle. Maintain similar delta (0.30-0.35) and OTM distance. CHALLENGED POSITION: If stock rallies above short strike, have three options: (1) Close entire position for profit (long call appreciated more than short call lost). (2) Buy back short call at loss, sell new call further out in time/price. (3) Accept assignment on short, exercise long call to deliver shares (rare - destroys remaining LEAPS time value). LEAPS DECAY MANAGEMENT: Monitor LEAPS time value. If <6 months remaining and significant time value left, consider rolling to new LEAPS further out. AVOID: Never let LEAPS get to <30 DTE - loses stock-like behavior. POSITION ADJUSTMENT: If stock drops significantly, can roll LEAPS down to lower strike to reduce cost basis and maintain delta.

DIAGONAL SPREAD GENERAL: Any spread where long and short options have different strikes AND different expirations. Can be calls or puts. Can be bullish or bearish. LONG CALL DIAGONAL: Buy longer-dated lower strike call, sell shorter-dated higher strike call. Identical to PMCC structure. LONG PUT DIAGONAL: Buy longer-dated higher strike put, sell shorter-dated lower strike put. Bearish strategy. PMCC SPECIFIC: Subset of diagonal spreads with specific parameters - LEAPS delta >0.75 (deep ITM), short call delta <0.35 (OTM), designed as stock replacement with income generation. COST-TO-WIDTH REQUIREMENT: TastyTrade specifies <75% for PMCC. General diagonals may not follow this rule. USE CASE DIFFERENCE: PMCC = stock ownership alternative with income. General diagonal spread = directional speculation or volatility play. RATIO DIAGONALS: Advanced variation - sell MULTIPLE short-dated options against one long-dated option. Increases income but also risk. Example: 1:2 ratio - buy 1 long call, sell 2 short calls.
